description: Past indicative of wit: from Old English witan, from Proto-Germanic *witaną, from Proto-Indo-European *weyd- (“see, know”). Cognate with Dutch weten, German wissen, Swedish veta, and Latin videō (“I see”). Compare guide.

entries.meaning: (archaic) simple past tense and past participle of wit.
examples: And lang ere witless Jeanie wist, / Her heart was tint, her peace was stown!

description: A misunderstanding, or a joking use of the past indicative of wit; see Etymology 1.

verbs.description: wist (third-person singular simple present wists, present participle wisting, simple past and past participle wisted)

entries.meaning: (nonstandard, pseudo-archaic) To know, be aware of.
